It's on the edge of downtown, but only a few short blocks to the CN tower which is next door to the Rogers Center. Toronto is a very easy city to enjoy on foot, and the transit system is terrific. We checked in at 3 p.m. and to our delight found we had been upgraded from a deluxe king room to a "luxury" king room--the difference being we now had a dressing area and a soaking tub. Our room, 302, was spacious and tastefully furnished, sleek and modern, and looked out over the courtyard. The king bed was deliciously comfortable, but the pillows were quite firm. However you can request whatever pillows you prefer through the concierge ( we didn't bother). There was lots of storage in the dressing area and in the marble clad bathroom. Plush bathrobes, towels and linens were provided as well as Molton Brown toiletries. There are switches at bedside that control room lights, bathroom lights, the curtains, and you can control the do not disturb/housekeeping requests from there, too. The heated floor in the bathroom has its own switch if you don't want it in the summer. There are 2 phones in the room and one in the bathroom, where there is also a speaker with volume control so you can hear what's on the TV in the bedroom. They've really thought of everything, and I felt the price we paid was an excellent value for what we got, especially with the upgrade. The staff was very polished, and the concierge got instant results when I requested a coveted table at nearby Canoe restaurant. There is a highly rated restaurant at the hotel (closed the Monday night we arrived) and Sen5es (sic) cafe off the lobby provides a *gourmet* breakfast buffet (about $23 per person) that we enjoyed once. It included hot dishes, smoked salmon, fresh fruit, some remarkably good dim sum (!), granola parfaits, and pastries from their bakery where you can also purchase decadent desserts and confections. We were treated to turn down service each night, and we never heard our neighbors. When the curtains are drawn, they effectively block out daylight. The wet bar is fully (and expensively) stocked, but they provide bottled water gratis with the evening visit. We walked everywhere from here. It was mostly a sports pilgrimage for my husband to visit the hockey hall of fame and the Rogers Center which were presented in such a way as to hold my interest as well. Though the Soho is on the edge of downtown, it's very pleasant to be a short walk away from the very busy tourist scene. We had an excellent breakfast at Cora's which resides on the corner diagonal from the Soho; there is a convenience market directly across the street for Maple Cream cookie cravings, and a large pharmacy at the end of the block for other sundries. It was a supremely serene and modern setting to return to at the end of each day where we were treated royally and easily tempted to return. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Senses! My hips are wider from having croissants every morning there...”
Reviews.Author: Iloveboutiquehotels
Reviews.Content: What a nice treat to stay in a hotel with an incredible bakery onsite! Being a Vancouverite I am familiar with Senses and Thomas Hass pastries, so I made a point of having my breakfast in Senses every morning. I must say however, the baristas in the Vancouver location make better lattes! Okay about the hotel... great staff, everyone was warm and welcoming, always tried to anticipate my needs before I even asked and they were very classy. I know they're marketing this hotel as a boutique hotel but somehow I didn't get that feel. It's hard to peg why I felt that way, maybe it's the long corridor to get to the room, long walks to the room always makes me think of a convention hotel. The rooms were decorated in a clean contemporary style but nothing that left an impression. It made me giggle when I saw picture frames decorated in rooms with the original generic picture left inside (b/w picture of a stylish woman and on the bottom said "umbra"!). Not a "boutique" touch don't you think? This is such a small detail but I had to add that! Molton Brown oatmeal soap was very nice, the shampoo and conditioner had a very masculine smell so I ended up using my back-up shampoo. I would stay at SoHo again on business but then there are many other hotels in Toronto to choose from at this cost. They need something extra to capture my loyalty.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Atmosphere and Decor!”
Reviews.Author: StephanieinOntario
Reviews.Content: We really enjoyed the SoHo. It was decorated exactly how I would decorate my own home...clean, modern, but warm and comfortable. Check in was easy, parking was simple, and the room exceeded our expectations. I am one PICKY customer, so that was a nice surprise. The bathroom was my favourite....heated marble, spotless, the remote control curtains, maid service, etc...everything was great, except their Restaurant Senses. It was rated well, so we were excited to have a fabulous meal. They no longer have a tasting menu as advertised, they were out of the two dishes I wanted to order, and when my husband ordered a port, they gave him the wrong one, and then tried to argue over it. Not good for a $375 plus meal for 2. However, breakfast at their bakery was excellent. Smoked salmon, cheeses, eggs anyway you want them...dim sum...but $20 a person. We would stay there again, but not waste our money on their restaurant.

Reviews.Title: “a quality, well run hotel”
Reviews.Author: CWS
Reviews.Content: Usually stay at one of the bigger chain hotels in Toronto. This time tried the Soho Met. Made for a refreshing change. Firstly the staff were some of the most professional I've encountered in a large hotel. The decor is very stylish and contemporary. The ambience is equally cool and calming. A standard room is an average size but the bathroom and dressing areas are real pluses. Would suggest anyone staying hear joins the hotels iprefer plan (gives you room upgrade, if available). This place really took the stress out of travelling and a welcome change to McHilton etc etc...

Reviews.Title: “Soho Met.. You rock!”
Reviews.Author: Tania123
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the Soho Residences during Christmas and New Year after coming from England. Yes it was extremely quiet during that time but the hotel staff made up for it and were extremely friendly. Lisa, Soraya and an another Gentleman whose name I have forgotten (the one who is getting married! Aaron?) were great and did their best to keep us entertained! The residences were bright, spacious and great value for money. My husband and I tend to spluge out when we go on holiday, we have stayed at Le Tousserok in Mauritius, Kanuhura in the Maldives and the Shangri-la in Sydney but the service we got from the Soho Met surpassed them all! We would go back in a shot... Soho Met and Toronto you are great!

Reviews.Title: “Definitely THE BEST”
Reviews.Author: Lukabijou
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Soho two times and each time was lovely. My most recent visit was over New Year's Eve weekend. (My husband and I were suprised to see some of the same staff who had been there over a year earlier still working there ). The rooms are great & spacious. The linens are nice, the bath products are nice and the large tubs are great for taking relaxing bubble baths. The only thing we though was odd is that the televisions seem to be old and clunky. They don't really fit in with the modern and sleek decor. The service is incredible. My husband had a stomach ache and I called down to the front desk to ask if they had any medicine. It was late--and they offered to run to the drug store to pick him up some Pepto. WOW! I was impresed. They also gave us humidifiers for our rooms (we were with 2 other couples) b/c the air was so dry. They went out of their way to find a place for us to eat on New Year's Day--and to confirm and change existing restaurant reservations. The staff is wonderful. I will definitely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Top Hotel”
Reviews.Author: English_Traveller-7
Reviews.Content: Where do I start? All the staff from the reception, bar, gym, concierge and restaurant were very friendly and helpful. The room was excellent, lovely bed, luxurious bathroom and huge wardrobe space (Important for the missus as she has lots of clothes). The pool and hot-tub were very nice, not big, but they werenâ€™t too crowded either. The bar was very modern but had a nice atmosphere and on the last night we decided to eat in the hotel restaurant, which was excellent. The location was spot on for access to the city centre and the waterfront, including the CN tower. I would definitely stay here again. The hotel is not cheap but is worth the money.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Getaway Hotel - Highly Recommended”
Reviews.Author: Franchise35
Reviews.Content: This hotel was great from start to finish! We wanted a 2 day getaway in Toronto (to see a show and go to a spa) and this hotel didn't disappoint. I signed up for the iPrefer program for free online. This led to us being upgraded to a Luxury room upon check-in. The room was very big and had all the amenities you could ask for. We liked the "walk in closet" concept and the bathroom was HUGE. (complete with soaker tub and heated floor...very cool!) The consierge was very helpful (Chris was his name) and gave us several good restaurant recommendations in the area. The Senses Bakery was very good (a little pricey but delicious food) and the Senses Bar was a great place to end the evening. (again, a bit pricey but the service was great!) The location of the hotel was good. All major sites were within walking distance (Eaton Center=10 minutes, Theatre District=5 minutes, etc). The only slight inconvenience was that the closest subway stop was a few blocks away. Not usually a big deal but in the middle of winter in Toronto it's nice to stay indoors in the PATH system as much as possible). We needed a cab to get to our show and Chris the consierge got us the complimentary hotel limo...very nice touch! Overall the location of the hotel, combined with the excellent service and posh surroundings made this a great place to stay. We got the internet rate which was only $50 a night more than staying at the Marriott or Sheraton (and the room was twice as big as something you would get at those places). We would not hesitate to stay here again for our next trip to Toronto!

Reviews.Title: “Not Luxurious as stated”
Reviews.Author: TravelNutsie
Reviews.Content: Upon arrival, we were upgraded to a luxury room...great, right? Just a higher floor, but small room. Your typical average minimalist wannabee W, minus the nice fluffy down pillows & cool furnishings. Concierge service was nonexistent. Our 1st experience with her(the tall brunette,) the bell boy had to come over to give us directions. The 2nd experience, she was helping a guest on the phone...okay that is legitimate, so we waited till she was finished. Soon after, she not only failed to aknowledge that we were right infront of her, but she picked up another call, this time it was a her friend. As she started to tell the friend that she wasn't doing anything much, we got fed up & went over to the front desk for help. Maybe concierge service means something different in Canada. Another annoyance, if you rent a car as we did for business, you can self park, but have to validate the ticket every day, otherwise you are denied exit from the property...they have to come up with a better system. Now for the plus...the bathroom was beautiful, big & the heated floors were great. Cute hotel, but not for the price. Next time, the Cospomolitan as was originally recommended by client.

Reviews.Title: “A fantastic hotel”
Reviews.Author: Minsters041
Reviews.Content: This is a fantastic hotel, the rooms are excellent, the staff friendly and helpful, the location great and the bathrooms amazing.

Reviews.Title: “A great hotel”
Reviews.Author: WillowG
Reviews.Content: I can't say enough about the high quality of this hotel. My company's travel agency booked me here on a recent business trip. The rooms are huge, with luxurious bathroom and vast closet space. There is a comfortable couch facing the TV. The lighting in the rooms is excellent for work and reading. High-speed internet connection is free--perfect for the business traveler. An excellent healthy breakfast buffet is available in the cafe. Best of all, the staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. The concierge even followed me to the front door to wave good-bye and wish me a safe flight home!

Reviews.Title: “Great luxury bathroom”
Reviews.Author: Champagneandcupcakes
Reviews.Content: I booked this hotel based on reviews here, and we were very happy with our room. Stayed in a luxury room on the 4th floor and didn't notice any street noise. The front desk and concierge service was solid and friendly, no matter who was working. We didn't eat there as there was a Cora's across the street and we ate breakfast there. Try Jump down the street for dinner. It was a bit expensive but a very good choice, in a good location, and there always seemed to be taxis waiting outside. There was a drugstore nearby for necessities and water. The marble bathroom had a heated floor and we loved it. We will stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “the SoHo was great”
Reviews.Author: Tamsay
Reviews.Content: My wife and I were married on October 1st and we wanted to stay at a nice hotel after the reception was over. We wanted to splurge on a nice hotel room for one night, so after intense researching we booked a night at the Soho. Well, we couldn't have made a better choice. We arrived at 1am and were greeted by friendly front desk staff who treated us with courtesy. The front desk gentleman upgraded us to a suite and gave us a late checkout. He also insisted on parking our rental car himself. As for the hotel room itself, we were given seasonal fruit and a complimentary bottle of champagne. The room was spectacular; it was well decorated, it had a plasma tv, a safe, writing desk and smart furniture. The bedroom very comfortable which made for a great night's sleep after such a busy day. The bathroom was beautiful. It had a large bath tub or a glass enclosed shower. It was wel lit and was covered in marble. We found the heated floors to be very nice, too. Is the SoHo expensive? Yes, but it is definitely worth it. The staff is friendly and professional and will always greet you with a smile. We definitely recommend the SoHo and we would go there again.

Reviews.Title: “A great stay, excellent value”
Reviews.Author: elegantraveller
Reviews.Content: We enjoyed our stay at the Soho very much indeed. Our room was comfortable, clean and well equipped and a peaceful refuge from the busy city. Sadly we couldn't eat at Senses restaurant since it was fully booked but we enjoyed an excellent meal at Rain, a stylish restaurant nearby. Yes, the neighbourhood is hardly the best, but the hotel is only a short walk away from all the main attractions.

Reviews.Title: “SoHo - Great Location, Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: MaxPower2006
Reviews.Content: I stayed in the SoHo while on a business trip as they were having a special that made it cheaper than the Royal York (where I usually stay when in town). The SoHo is one block north of Front Street on the western side of the downtown core. It was a nice 10 minute walk to get to Bay and Yonge where my meetings were (as opposed to a 3 or 4 minute walk from the Royal York). What I love about the SoHo however, is that it is a smallish hotel, no where near the size of the Royal York and because of that there was much more personalized attention. After I checked in, I went across the street to Wayne Gretzky's bar to have a beer while I watched the hockey game and when I came back the concierge greeted me by name - which is the sort of personalized touch that is so great with a boutique hotel. The restaurant in the hotel (Senses?) was very good if not a bit pricey, especially if you are not on an expense account. The mix of people in the hotel seemed to be business travellers, youngish "hipsters" and Europeans (met a nice guy from Paris who was in town with his girlfriend on business). No kids evident. The rooms were larger than I would expect and the bathrooms were amazing, so far above Royal York level I couldn't even compare them - huge walk-in with a heated floor and top notch toiletries. The bed linen was great (easily compares to Westin/Hyatt level of beds) and I liked the novelty of the auto-blinds. As has been noted in previous reviews, my view (I was on the 6th floor I think) was of a building under-construction, but which appeared to be close to completion - looks like a condo. I was never bothered by any noise. This area is a very trendy with lots of high end condos around. There is a parking lot adjacent as well. Reading through the reviews, I am surprised to see no one commented on the great night-time views of the big building lights. I quite liked that. Also, it was one block away from King St (lots of restaurants and theatres) and about 3 blocks from Queen St (lots of shops). One block from the Rogers Centre (Blue Jays games) and two blocks from the CN Tower. You are right smack in the middle of the downtown hustle and bustle, don't expect a stunning view of the lake and you will not be disappointed. I really liked the area and will be returning when I come back to Toronto on business.

Reviews.Title: “Location, location...but no view”
Reviews.Author: Craven
Reviews.Content: I do not think you could find a better location than this in Toronto. Most things are close by both from a business and entertainment point of view. The view from most bedrooms ranges from average to poor but if you do not want to stare out the window it is not a problem. Some roomes at the back are quite overlooked but they have see thru sun blinds on the windows that protect ones modesty! The first room I got was (I think ) #434. This room is smaller than most and right next to the lifts which have the loudest bell tones I have ever heard so avoid if you want a good sleep. I got moved to one further down the corridoor and found it very adequate. There are good working facilities with plenty of light, a comfy bed and a large TV with numerous channels and film options. The bathroom was excelent and there is plenty of hanging space for ones clothes in a seperate area. The public areas are very pleasant in a boutique kind of way. There is a trendy bar with excelent staff and a very adequate dining room. Breakfasts are nothing to write home about but again quite adequate. If you want to find somewhere not too expensive (but top quality) to eat try just around the corner at the cafe/restaurant called Spoon. I stumbled upon it and had a memorable meal. So, if you avoid any rooms near the noisy lift and do not care about views give this place a try. i think you will enjoy it.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic”
Reviews.Author: ADpsufan
Reviews.Content: Located within walking distance to Rodgers Center, Chinatown, Air Canada Center, Yonge St, you name it. Very clean. Bathroom is out of this world. Heated floors!! Room is neat and clean... not the greatest view.. a parking lot lot, but we did not care. Staff is knowledgable and polite. Would recommend it to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “Stylish hotel, and close to restaurants and bars..”
Reviews.Author: kugaloo
Reviews.Content: First time in Toronto and I was a little lost at first. Called the hotel and spoke to Ryan the Concierge who was very helpful and very patient when I called 3 times as I got closer. Doorman immediately met me at front door and parked my car in the hotel. Valet parking was $30 can. and self park was $25 can per night. Very impressed upon first entering the hotel and met with Ryan who showed me my luxury room. Room was amazing but had a so so view of a construction site across the street. I stayed in 417 and maybe you want to inquire as to the view before you book. The staff are very friendly and helpful. The bar downstairs is very cool and worth a drinky before you go out, and when you come back for a nightcap. The bakery also in the lobby serves a wonderful gourmet self serve breakfast/brunch for about 22 can (i think).. The luxury room was $198 can. and in my opinion, well worth the quality and location. If you like to stay in nice, stylish hotel rooms this will not disappoint. Although I was here to party for one night, I was tremendously pleased with the service and overall quality.

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding!!!!!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My partner and I were desperate for a place to stay after a horrible night in another hotel the night before. We called the SoHo Met and they were reasonably priced so we moved there. This place exceeded our expectations!!! We stayed in the long term self-contained apartment accommodation side of the hotel (stays of longer than 7 days) and we loved it. The bed and bathroom were out of this world and the room came with internet access and computer (for a small extra charge) We had access to the gym and pool which was also great. This is one of the best places I have ever stayed - would recommend without a second thought!!!!

Reviews.Title: “One of the best hotels in North America”
Reviews.Author: horns1
Reviews.Content: I stayed in the SoHo from Dec. 24-28 and now have a favorite hotel! Previously I had thought no one could match the service and amenities of a Rosewood Hotel (see Hotel Crescent Court or Mansion on Turtle Creek in Dallas) but the SoHo exceeded their high standards. The property is beautiful and just the right size for a personal feel for each guest, but maintaining the granduer of a special hotel experience. The rooms are very large and the walk in closet configuration should be adopted by more hotels along with the ample bathrooms. Senses is a great restaurant and though a little more than Cora's across the street the breakfast buffet is worth it. Of course the deserts are great and just right for a late night treat! But the best part of the hotel were the peolpe - On Christmas day there were only 18 guest in the hotel, but everything was fully staffed and extra efforts were made to accomadate us on the holiday. From locating a movie theater and show times for us, to enjoyable conversation in the bar - the staff was a true joy. Everyone made the effort to know you on a first name basis and it was not pretencious - but seemed genuine. I cannot say enough - if staying in Toronto, there is no match to the SoHo.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Location”
Reviews.Author: gabe05
Reviews.Content: This hotel has a great location, unlike the Yorkville hotels where you have to take a cab or subway to get downtown. The Soho is close to Toronto's finest restaurants and hottest night clubs and a short walk to the Theater district which came in handy during Toronto's cold weather. The rooms were breathtaking with curtains that closed with a flick of a switch and heated marble bathroom floors. Staff was help full and showed me how the gadgets in the room worked. The Soho has great package deals during the weekends I would definitely stay here again. I just hope they get rid of the paper coffee cups in the rooom!

Reviews.Title: “nice stay at the Soho Met”
Reviews.Author: varvararodriques
Reviews.Content: I like the SOHO Met a lot. The room was nice with a great bathroom. Loved the heated floors. As someone else mentioned no plasma TV. Oh well. The bed was very nice. Service was pleasant and I had no problems with my reservation or bill. Location of the hotel is good. We had breakfast at Cora's across the street, great food and MUCH less expensive than at the Senses bakery/cafe. I had expected wireless internet in the room as they advertise with wireless throughout the hotel. This turned out not to be the case. There is wireless in the lobby only and the room has broadband with a ethernet cable. This was a downside because I wanted to be able to be connected at the same time my roommate was. We had two laptops.The good news is that it is free. Overall a good experience.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel but........”
Reviews.Author: tersanna
Reviews.Content: I am from Toronto and we decided to spend a few days R & R downtown and be pampered. The room at the SOHO was beutiful and the bathroom was very impressive. Room service came in (it seemed) everytime we left our room and cleaned it. But there were a few little things wrong, which for the price supprised me. They said the rooms all had surround sound.. Ours did not. The tv was not plasma. The central controls for the lights did not work. The light bulb in the makeup mirror was out. We were given free tea or coffee, but nothing to drink it out of. On check out, we tried to use the fast checkout on the TV. But It came up with someone elses name. So when we checked out the the front desk, there was a movie on my bill which we could not have rented, as we were out the time it was rented. I don't think I will bother going there again.

Reviews.Title: “Exceptional Hotel - Highly Recommended”
Reviews.Author: Londoner1974
Reviews.Content: As someone who travels frequently throughout North America I see my fair share of hotels, some good, others not so good but the SoHo Metropolitan was undoubtedly among the very best. The checkin was swift, friendly and very efficient. The room I was given was superb - enormous and with a private outside terrace with a table and seating for four. The room was very stylishly decorated with unusually good art-work and a plasma TV and DVD. Drapes are controlled electronically by a switch by the bed and the do-not disturb sign is engaged electronically by a button next to the door. The bathroom contined the feel of quality with below floor heating and a massive walk-in shower. The restaurant (the name of which escapes me) was also excellent with quality service if, predictably, on the pricey side. Only gripe was the lack of an ironing board and iron but this is a minor consideration for what was one of the most pleasant hotel experiences I have had in some time. Will undoubtedly stay here again when I next go to Toronto.

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We spent three nights at the SoHo Metropolitan and loved it. It's a stylish hotel in a good a location. The rooms, especially the bathrooms, are wonderful. I highly recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “We'd stay there again, but you should know...”
Reviews.Author: cincioh2002
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Soho Metro four nights in July 2005. First of all, we agreed that the room itself was one of the best non-suite rooms we'd ever stayed in, if not the best. The marble bathroom was amazing with heated floors, plenty of lights and storage, a deep soaking/whirlpool tub that was great after exploring the city all day, and a glass enclosed, two shower-head shower (see picture - sorry about quality). The king bed was very comfortable, and the room was quite spacious - enough to hang out in or rest in without feeling claustrophobic. The location was great for summer explorers; it was only a couple of blocks from Queen Street, King Street, Gardinier Expy, Rogers Field, and there were many great restaurants within easy walking distance, which really simplified our evenings. Parking, while always expensive in larger cities, was not unreasonable, and the secured garage was clean, well-lit, and convenient to the hotel (park and take an elevator up one floor to the lobby). Additionally, my wireless internet connection for my laptop worked from the room for no charge (this was luck - try it and see if yours works, if not, you can purchase a cable for $10). For a warm weather trip, we would stay there again without hesitation. Having said that, there are some things which should be pointed out: (1) For the cost-conscious: If you enjoy a cocktail or five in the evenings, and don't want to leave the hotel, be prepared to spend a small fortune in the hotel bar - if I recall correctly, a moderate quality glass of wine cost $14 CAN. This was easily remedied as there is a small establishment (Pizza Rustico) across the street where we went each evening and were able to purchase a 1/2 liter of our favorite wine for slightly less. (2) For the cost-conscious: The hotel offers very few inexpensive alternatives (i.e. I'm cheap, and this hotel is not). The bakery, the mini bar in the room, the restaurant etc. were comparatively some of the most expensive I've seen. Once again, because of the location, this was easily solved by a 5 minute walk. There is a breakfast place across from the hotel that served wonderful breakfasts at a reasonable cost. We are adventurous diners, and given the number of interesting restaurants so close to us, we did not try the hotel bakery or restaurant, though we were told numerous times they were excellent by non-hotel staff. (3) The front door service was inconsistent. Sometimes there was a doorman, sometimes not. Sometimes they opened the door, sometimes not. Upon our arrival, we had to go inside to find someone to ask about parking as no doorman was present, which made for a poor first impression. We were told to park in the garage below the hotel, which we did. Upon arriving in the lobby with all of our bags, we were THEN asked if we needed assistance. I suppose we could have gone up, gotten a bellman, brought him down to the car to get our belongings, and then returned to the lobby, but that seems a little bizarre to me. (4) The hallways in the hotel looked a little run down because of the carpeting - there are large squares in the carpet with are fraying at the seams. Without getting into details, it made us a little concerned that this hotel was past its heyday and made the place look a little beat up. Our concerns disappeared upon reaching the room which was immaculate. (5) Views. The hotel is on the first few floors of the building only. If you are hoping for a skyline view, or some other extremely scenic view, you will be disappointed. Our view was of the building across the street, and a little ways in either direction, but it was fine, if not scenic. There are plenty of places to go in the city if you want a scenic view, and just traveling around the city will give you several views. We felt the room quality was more important than the view. We had a great stay, and would definitely stay here again, but I would have liked to have known these things ahead of time.

Reviews.Title: “It was ok”
Reviews.Author: RB77
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Soho for a night in April 2005. After a lot of internet research for boutique hotels, I chose this one. The rooms are exactly as shown on the website, very large, spacious, clean and a nice decor. My room was on the second floor, right off of the elevator, which I was not too happy about. Even though the occupancy was low at the time, they did not accomodate my original request to be in a room furthest from the elevators! I did not know that the hotel only has five or six floors, and the rest of the building is private condiminiums. My view was awful (looking on to a public parking lot). The website stated "windows that open" this was one of my main reasons for booking this hotel, as I am a smoker and like to have a constant flow of fresh air. The window must have opened up about 4-5 inches and that was it! Loved the Molton Brown toiletries! All in all, it was a nice hotel, but I wouldn't particularly stay there again...I rather try out some of the other new boutique hotels in Toronto.

Reviews.Title: “lovely luxury in Toronto”
Reviews.Author: Corgimom
Reviews.Content: Stayed for one night in early July. Wasn't sure about our choice, but didn't want to stay in a huge chain. This hotel was a delight in most ways. We checked in at 1:30pm. I believe we paid $204 canadian. Parking was overpriced at $22 per day. The small lobby is very chic and a bit overstaffed (three desk clerks, two concierges and two doormen, but everyone was very helpful. Our room was on the second floor, so I expected no view, but was pleasantly surprised. Since the room looked exactly like the photo advertised on TripAdvisor, I won't repeat it, but check out our view of the CN tower (attached). The room was smallish but gorgeous. White fluffy linens (a few more pillows would have been nice). Great artwork, a large TV (that pulled out and swiveled for viewing from the bed) and a few chic extras like push button drapes, dimmable lighting and a do not disturb/housekeeping button. A small minibar with drinks, coffeemaker and munchies came in handy (at a price). There is a market across the street if you don't want to partake of a $3.50 can of Coke. The bathroom is to-die-for. Light oak wooden shelves, a bench and a safe in the dressing area held everything we brought. Fluffy robes and lots of hangars, plus big drawers make it a closet you'd love to have every trip. The bathroom itself is large but not overly so (a separate toilet room would have made it perfect). Marble floor heated on command, and the bathtub is huge. The glass shower is regular size, but with two shower heads. The toiletries were very luxurious. A lighted makeup mirror was a nice touch, but a stool to sit on while applying makeup would have made it easier to use. All in all, a very nice room. Our only disappointment was that the air conditioner would never get quite cool enough, even at it's lowest setting. Perhaps it was the record breaking heatwave outside. The Senses bakery was pretty and very convenient, although everything seemed a bit too "over-the-top" in presentation and exotic spices. The hotel is just down the street from the Ballpark and the CN Tower, plus only three blocks away from the theater district and the Queen Street Antique area. I have never seen so many young, thin, and beautiful people in one stroll, not even in California. Maybe all the starlets and model wannabees are now living in Toronto. We did have a problem with the smog/air pollution on our visit. We could never see Lake Ontario with any ease due to the haze. The Soho was a gem, though. I would definitely stay at this hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “Splendid hotel in a splendid city”
Reviews.Author: islandlover
Reviews.Content: Room was huge and staff was marvelous. Early check in was requested and was available. Concierge was knowledgable and helpful. Rate was very reasonable for a hotel of this quality--in New York it would have cost three times more; in London it wouldn't even be available! I'd love to go back to this hotel.
